# Demethylation

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

**Demethylation** is the chemical process resulting in the removal of a
[methyl group](/wiki/Methyl_group "Methyl group") (CH3) from a molecule.[1][2]
A common way of demethylation is the replacement of a methyl group by a
hydrogen atom, resulting in a net loss of one carbon and two hydrogen atoms.

The counterpart of demethylation is [methylation](/wiki/Methylation
"Methylation").

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 In biochemistry
  * 2 In organic chemistry
    * 2.1 _O_ -Demethylation
    * 2.2 _N_ -Demethylation
  * 3 References
  * 4 See also

## In
biochemistry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Demethylation&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: In biochemistry")]

In [biochemical](/wiki/Biochemical "Biochemical") systems, the process of
demethylation is [catalyzed](/wiki/Catalyst "Catalyst") by
[demethylases](/wiki/Demethylase "Demethylase"). These enzymes oxidize
N-methyl groups, which occur in [histones](/wiki/Histone "Histone") and some
forms of DNA:

    R2N-CH3 \+ O → R2N-H + CH2O

One such oxidative enzyme family is the [cytochrome
P450](/wiki/Cytochrome_P450 "Cytochrome P450").[3] [Alpha-ketoglutarate-
dependent hydroxylases](/wiki/Alpha-ketoglutarate-dependent_hydroxylase
"Alpha-ketoglutarate-dependent hydroxylase") are active for demethylation of
DNA, operating by similar pathway. These reactions exploit the weak C-H bond
adjacent to amines.

## In organic
chemistry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Demethylation&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: In organic chemistry")]

### _O_
-Demethylation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Demethylation&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: O-Demethylation")]

Demethylation typically refers to cleavage of ethers, especially aryl ethers,
although there are some exceptions, for instance _cf._
"[desipramine](/wiki/Desipramine "Desipramine")".

Apparently, aryl ethers are pervasive in [lignin](/wiki/Lignin
"Lignin")-derived compounds.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The reaction typically requires harsh conditions or harsh reagents. For
example, the methyl ether in [vanillin](/wiki/Vanillin "Vanillin") can be
removed by heating near 250 °C with strong base.[4] Stronger nucleophiles such
as diorganophosphides (LiPPh2) also cleave aryl ethers under milder
conditions.[5]

[Boron tribromide](/wiki/Boron_tribromide "Boron tribromide") is a classical
reagent for the dealkylation of methyl arylethers. The mechanism of ether
dealkylation proceeds via the formation of a complex between the boron center
and the ether oxygen followed by the elimination of an alkyl bromide to yield
a dibromo(organo)[borane](/wiki/Borane "Borane"). The dibromo(organo)borane
can then undergo [hydrolysis](/wiki/Hydrolysis "Hydrolysis") to give the
alcohol or phenol, [boric acid](/wiki/Boric_acid "Boric acid"), and [hydrogen
bromide](/wiki/Hydrogen_bromide "Hydrogen bromide") as products.[6]

    ROR + BBr3 → RO+(−BBr3)R
    RO+(−BBr3)R → ROBBr2 \+ RBr
    ROBBr2 \+ 3 H2O → ROH + B(OH)3 \+ 2 HBr

Methyl esters also are susceptible to demethylation, which is usually achieved
by [saponification](/wiki/Saponification "Saponification"). Highly specialized
demethylations are abundant such as the [Krapcho
decarboxylation](/wiki/Krapcho_decarboxylation "Krapcho decarboxylation"):

    [![Krapcho reaction.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Krapcho_reaction.svg/400px-Krapcho_reaction.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Krapcho_reaction.svg)

### _N_
-Demethylation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Demethylation&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: N-Demethylation")]

_N_ -demethylation of 3° amines is by the [von Braun
reaction](/wiki/Von_Braun_reaction "Von Braun reaction"), which uses
[BrCN](/wiki/BrCN "BrCN") as the [reagent](/wiki/Reagent "Reagent") to give
the corresponding _[nor-](/wiki/Nor- "Nor-")_ derivatives. A modern variation
of the [Von Braun reaction](/wiki/Von_Braun_reaction "Von Braun reaction") was
developed where BrCN was superseded by [ethyl
chloroformate](/wiki/Ethyl_chloroformate "Ethyl chloroformate"). The
preparation of [Paxil](/wiki/Paxil "Paxil") from [arecoline](/wiki/Arecoline
"Arecoline") is an application of this reaction, as well as the synthesis of
[GSK-372,475](/wiki/NS-2359 "NS-2359"), for example.
